SENT.plain: Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are clonal stem cell disorders, characterized by ineffective and dysplastic hematopoiesis
MDS patients have a defective immune response manifested by increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, autoimmune phenomena, and high incidence of lymphoid malignancies

Presently, we investigated the phenotype and function of monocyte-derived dendritic cells (MoDC) in 23 MDS patients and 15 controls at different stages of differentiation using the maturation stimuli tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) and LPS
Monocytes from MDS patients showed low potential to differentiate into dendritic cells (DC), as determined by low cell yield and CD1a expression
MDS-MoDCs exhibited low expression of mannose receptor and reduced endocytic capacity
MDS-MoDCs showed a diminished response to TNF-alpha with low CD83, CD80, and CD54 expression and allostimulatory capacity
In patients with 5q syndrome, monocytes and MoDCs were positive for the 5q deletion, suggesting their origin from the malignant clone
Our data indicate that MoDCs in MDS display quantitative and functional abnormalities that may contribute to the defective immune response of these patients
